reasoning:
The critique targets the essay’s Pivot P3: the claim that (under the most plausible intertheoretic-comparison methods) unbounded views should loom larger under moral uncertainty, making the “fairest” aggregations fussy and thus giving the no-easy-eutopia conclusion decision-theoretic bite. That’s a meaningful part of the essay’s synthesis, but not the core of the overall case: much of the essay argues that most plausible *single* moral views are fussy and that eutopia is fragile even without aggregating across views. So centrality is moderate rather than high.

On strength: the critique mainly highlights contingency/underdetermination (normalization choice matters; alternative normalizations could reverse the practical recommendation), and demands a principled defense or a more conditional conclusion. This does weaken the robustness of P3, but it doesn’t show that the authors’ preferred normalizations are wrong—only that they’re contestable and that other reasonable choices exist. Also, the essay already acknowledges the thorniness and that different methods disagree, which reduces how much the critique newly damages the position.

Correctness is fairly high: it is true that intertheoretic scaling can swing recommendations and that, without a defensible scaling story, “all-things-considered” guidance under moral uncertainty is less robust. The main overreach is suggesting the overall “no easy eutopia” thesis loses decision relevance entirely; it still has bite conditional on many individual theories being fussy (and on the essay’s non-uncertainty arguments). The critique is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: The conclusion hinges on contested intertheoretic normalization that can reverse rankings
